field_edited_text.value:
Recent photograph of Locust Point, Key Highway; Inner Harbor, upper right

Key Highway: The waterfront land
along Key Highway stretching from the
Inner Harbor, south and then east to
Amstar Sugar holds unique potential for
redevelopment.

The former Bethlehem Steel Key
Highway Ship Repair Yard was purchased in
1984 by a developer. The City, community
and the developer have initiated a plannin
process to formulate plans for the site. All
participants in this effort are concerned
that consensus is reached as to the mix of
land uses, number of residential units,
public access to the shoreline, water uses
and impacts on the South Baltimore
community.

East of the former ship repair yard are
a number of smaller parcels. Although
several are vacant or underutilized, the Cit
views this area as a resource for future
employment. Also located along this
shoreline are a City-owned facility for
repair of fire equipment and the Baltimore
Museum of Industry. Any redevelopment
of this area will include the proposed
expansion of the Baltimore Museum of
Industry and provision of public shoreline
access, when reasonable.

Land Under Interstate-95 - Six oblong
sites ranging in size from .5 to 1.8 acres
located under the elevated portion of the
expressway between Hanover Street and
Key Highway might be suitably developed
as parking or open storage yards for nearb
industries.

Port Covington East - Approximately

60 acres of land lies east of B.G.&E.’s Gould

treet Station. This property, which is City-
owned and leased to the Western Mary-
land Railway until the early 21st century,
offers potential for expanded port opera-
tions. Current plans are to turn over the
property to the Port Administration for
expansion of the South Locust Point
Marine Terminal.

Wells Street Area - Older industrial
areas in Baltimore like Carroll Industrial
Park have benefited from public improve-
ments and public administrative assistance
in marketing vacant properties. Businesses
in the vicinity of Wells Street might also
benefit from such an approach. Funds from
the federal Economic Development Admin-
istration were used to reconstruct Wells
Street. Two development opportunities
present themselves immediately. The first is
a vacant, dilapidated building on a 2.6-acre
site at the southeast corner of Wells and
Charles Street. The building could be razed
and the site offered for redevelopment.
There are also opportunities for marketing
buildings to maritime users.

Bethlehem Steel Fort McHenry Yard -
With the construction work on Interstate-95
completed, a 16-acre parcel may become
available for redevelopment in a water-
related or water-dependent use.
